body:
### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.5.1

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, vim 8.2.3441

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

Linux console

### $TERM environment variable

linux

### Installation

Official Arch repo

### How to reproduce the issue

Open any text without a display server, try highlighting it in visual mode

### Expected behavior

Text gets highlighted in the terminal (same as vim)

### Actual behavior

Text doesn't get highlighted, making it harder to use the visual mode

comment_data.body: Maybe it is a failure to detect 8-color terminal?
Just to make sure: you are talking about the standard Linux console you get when you are booting into runlevel 3 or below? If so, please add more details on your system (Linux kernel version etc.)
I think OP meant Virtual Console (getty) created by systemd.

Neovim should automatically add `cterm=reverse` to `Visual` highlight group in `default` colorscheme if terminal is 8-colors, but here it fails to detect that. Note that `colors` is `256` instead of `8`.

Maybe this is terminfo/unibilium problem?

or a faulty assumption on Neovim's side: `:h tui-colors` states
```
Nvim uses 256 colours by default, ignoring terminfo for most terminal types,
including "linux" (whose virtual terminals have had 256-colour support since
4.8) and anything claiming to be "xterm".  Also when $COLORTERM or $TERM
contain the string "256".
```

> Nvim uses 256 colours by default, ignoring terminfo for most terminal types, including "linux" (whose virtual terminals have had 256-colour support since 4.8)

yep. but see also the commit messages in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/5001 . 

Open to improving edge cases, but note that we absolutely favor compromises for terminal quirks, if it makes startup more deterministic (which matters for remote UIs): https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/9829

> or a faulty assumption on Neovim's side

That seems to be it. Linux kernel does "support" 256 colors, however it simply downgrades the color depth.

edit: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a161559a006bcbc31a2eccbd96df3138e8bc3bc5/src/nvim/tui/tui.c#L1754 seems to be the issue, let me try and fix this

Maybe we just need to adjust the Visual highlight so that it downgrades to something more reasonable? We want to change the default colorscheme anyway. Default `Visual` should just be "white" for bg=dark, and "black" for bg=light.
with my PR, the only issue left is no highlight color with tmux, but not sure that's easily fixable without changing the default colors
The new default colorscheme doesn't have this issue, but `&t_Co` still seems incorrect in Linux Console (it should be 8, but it is 256).

Yep. The problem here is an unclear definition of what "supports 256 colors" means.

Does the Linux console _interpret_ 256-color values? Yes.

Does it _render_ 256 colors? No, it maps them down to its 16-color palette (backgrounds are even 8-colors only).

So, to a script or colorscheme that tries to "progressively enhance" based on the terminal's capabilities, it doesn't matter whether the terminal can understand the escape sequences; it matters whether it actually displays things in the intended way.

The Linux console does not display 256 colors, so it should be set to "supports 16 foreground and 8 background colors", if that's possible.

Since `&t_Co` is used by quite a few scripts & colorschemes to dynamically change their behavior, but writing to `&t_Co` is not allowed, we can't even add a workaround like

```vim
if $TERM == 'linux'
    let &t_Co = 16
endif
```

to our config. :(

milestone.description: We don't plan to work on this, but will accept high quality contributions from someone who will own the feature and follow up on bug reports.

title: &t_Co has wrong value in Linux console
